reviewText:
This game is a trainwreck on wheels but its still a fun short ride for what it is.  The game is an old school button masher mostly just hit the x button for attack, there is a kick button but its not needed.  The game is low budget and the devs did a great job with what little it seems like they had budget wise to work with.  They opted out of cut scenes using a comic panel style to spend more time and money on the game itself.  The gameplay is fun and easy for anyone to play, just hit everything in sight.  The action stays fresh because you can switch turtles to use their different weapons.

Most of the game is very dark and some parts are just entirely pitch black or unfinished maybe?  The camera is zoomed in real close and for some reason seems to point down alot making it one of those games where you fight the camera.  The combat is like a cheap version of Batman but somehow balanced very well.  In batman the combat is fluid while in this its stunted leaving your character swinging weapons in the air while facing an enemy.  The game is real short almost to the point of feeling like its just an episode which would be great if they make more but it seems like the game is just left to rot even though people worked hard on it.  All the turtles look sorta strange with elongated limbs and necks, so does April which must be some artistic choice like with Splinter where he looks more like a werewolf than a rat.

Even with all those negatives the game is still a fun beat em up brawler that anyone can pick up and play anytime without complex controls to master which is great and satisfying to play.  Lots of fun dialog makes all those things you should hate about the game fade into the background somehow.  Its really true magic to play a game riddled with normally gamebreaking mechanics and yet still have fun doing it.

reviewText:
Out of the Shadows is a tragic case of Activision being Activision. The game is much better than the two recent games released on XBOX 360 based off of the television series (TMNT and TMNT:DOTO), but yet this installment leaves such a foul taste in the mouth when thinking about it. The game is unfinished, with extemely low-quality textures and low-quality audio on both music, and voice acting that sounds like it was recorded with tin cans instead of proper microphones (even if the Voice Actors themselves are talented, they sound ♥♥♥♥ here). The low-quality textures are hidden under attrocious lighting effects created by what feels like a gimped version of Unreal 3, and if you could see the models, you'd notice that they ended up doing a copy-pasta job in most levels, meaning that levels look the same all over, making it easy, especially in the opening level, to get lost in the subway tunnel section and end up running into invisible walls if you aren't paying attention and miss the train platforms.

The gameplay, with more work again would have been immensely satisfying. Although movement and combat animation and responses feels somewhat floaty, the game actually does make a good button masher with some Batman Arkham combat elements thrown in, barring counters which feel unresponsive in some areas. When played with the under-developed practise/arcade mode, which throws you into a more traditional TMNT arcade game-like world, the game really comes into its own, playing really well and actually being enjoyable. The problem is that this is not the main game, but this side-mode is so much more fun than the base game. I was never able to play multiplayer, due to Activision never patching the multiplayer service to actually work without tricks and external tweaking, and the fact that I couldn't get any of my friends on Steam to buy it because they thought it looked like ♥♥♥♥ based on the promotional material.

In the end, TMNT Out of the Shadows feels like an absolute failure, and that's because it is. Activision pushed out a game that would never come into its own because they prefered to pretend it didn't exist. The game, in the state you can buy it in is an absolute insult to the franchise, and shows what Activision thinks of the licenses it holds. As much as I wish I could recommend it to people, I have to tell people to avoid it like the plague. Then again, that isn't too hard, the game is dead, and although still on sale, I don't think anyone would buy it anyway, unless you're a mad fan who feels the need to play every TMNT game.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of the classic 90s arcade style brawlers like turtles in time(hyperstone hiest was my favorite) I have to say that this is the first game in well over a decade that quenches the thirst to relive those awesome moments. In short bursts though.

3 cons I want to get out of the way first;

-the camera has a mind of its own and at times doesn't zoom far enough out or let you look up and down enough to figure out where to go. It's an extra thing to combat when your already trying to do moves.

-the main story missions feel really short(5 hours to complete) feels like with how complicated the game is it should of been waaay longer and the way the story goes i get the vibe that they started out with great ideas then they became uninterested.

-the combat is a pro and con at the same time. The input lag is really slow and found myself inputting stuff twice to get stuff happening, usually resulting in the turtle doing the same move twice. I get why they did this, which is why it's a pro, the combat feels very good and satisfying, not like a hack n slash where you press a few buttons and your character goes nuts hitting everything around him (I hate those type of games) but more like playing an actual fighting game but in brawler mode, if anyone has ever played tekken 3s arcade brawler mode its kinda similar to that. It just feels really good and the animations are really well done and because of this theres a bit of input lag, and it does get frustrating to master at first.

OK now the good points.

The rpg leveling elements put alot of AAA titles these days to shame. And it's kind of overwhelming. You won't be going max level with your first play through of the story, not by a long shot. I've only played through once so far and I've gotten all the turtles around 20%. So yeah your going to either be playing arcade mode or playing the story missions alot.

This isn't actually a bad thing. The levels are actually really fun to play and the enemies keep getting harder and come at you in bigger numbers. I absolutely love that about the old snes games. A couple of boss fights are absolutely epic and I'd love to play them over and over again.

Each turtle has their own personality and fighting animations, and it really shines awesomely in this game. The voice acting as they converse with eachother and as you play them are really great and brings them all out really well. Each of them have their own fighting styles and moves, all completely unique animations from eachother. It's something you really have to experience for yourself to appreciate how well it's been done.

Everything about this game screams AAA. You really get a sense that they worked extremely hard at this game. And then pulled the plug too soon. The game feels really short, disappointingly short. The first boss you beat gets away, and I thought hey, we'll get him later and it'll be even more epic, and then it never happens. I can't help but think of everything it could of been. But everything it is now is still extremely fun to play. It'll be something I go back to for sure.

reviewText:
The Good:
Having all four brothers on-screen regardless of player number is major, providing much needed atmosphere that, for many TMNT games, was lacking if you were like me and didn't have enough friends interested in going to the arcade.
The dialogue is great, and goes even further to bring the atmosphere together.
The animations for the turtles are super, and so are their individual fighting styles. I certainly believe RedFly when they say they are TMNT fans, as it's evident in the care they took to make each turtle feel like an individual and contributing member of the group.
The classic arcade option allows some couch-coop, which is always a welcome bonus.

The Bad:
It's quite short. Now this game is $15 brand new, and I've seen $60 games offer less content, but it still doesn't feel like that epic turtle adventure that I'd have gladly paid $60 for.
There is a rather small assortment of enemies. This can be somewhat overlooked by the length of the game, but even just varying up textures would've made a difference.
Have I mentioned that it's short? Well, it doesn't quite get around to exploring enough of the adversaries that the turtles encounter in their usual adventures. In fact, we get to fight Karai twice, though to be fair, the first time isn't much of a boss fight. I remember one of the Dev Interviews saying something about planning some Casey Jones DLC at one point, but I'd be less surprised to get a Half-Life 3 confirmation than to hear another positive peep out of RedFly/Activision on this one.

The Ugly:
In many places it is possible to step outside or be forceably moved outside of the normal level boundaries. This didn't occur for me very often, but when it did, it was pretty frustrating.
The multiplayer is terribly broken, and by that, I mean that many people are unable to connect to others without means of a third party networking client, and even then only the host gets to keep their save data.
Here's the worst part. Remember all that energy and excitement that RedFly put into all the interview segments? The same excitement that had me ITCHING to tear into this game, and hopefully eventually chat with some of the devs because you could see that they were getting high on turtle power? Yeah, that all dried up and went the way of the dodo on launch day. We are left with a facebook page that doesn't really do anything but pass along less than helpful information, a less than satisfying page on Activision's website, and no real communication. We have received a patch that, among other things, removed the LAN option(it wasn't working anyway, but this was a bass-ackwards step) and aside from the poor PSN community who only recently got the game at all, we've received no further communication. The ball was severely dropped here, although it's hard to say if we should point fingers at RedFly or just assume Activision is being Activision and if it's not CoD it doesn't matter.

Do I recommend this game? My answer is complicated, because despite how absolutely broken the game is in many of its facets, I still had a good time with it. And while it has DEFINITELY made me skeptical of future RedFly releases, I hope that any TMNT fan can get past the issues with this game and have as much fun as I did. I recommend this game ONLY to fans of the TMNT, and even then, I strongly urge you to prepare yourself by reading the forums if you plan to attempt multiplayer, and reading other reviews. To the rest of you, I could never in good conscience recommend this game.

Ok, a warning beforehand: I am biased toward anything Turtles. It doesn't matter if it's a turd with a red bandana, I am bound to like it. With that out of the way, let's get this review trucking.

Out of the Shadows is a freeflow combat beat 'em up loosly adapted from the 2012 Nickelodeon reboot of the series. If you haven't seen that yet, give it a shot. It captures much of the old magic in a more modern and sensible jacket than the 80s cartoon. The game however, wears a different coat. The Turtles all have a more realistic look; they look like genuine mutants. This is probably the most striking feature of the game, because it departs from the appearances we's come be familliar with.

The gameplay itself though is a bit of a mix between Batman Arkham Asylum and Turtles in Time. You control one Turtle at a time, but you can switch at the touch of a button. You fight your way through hordes of mooks by using wel timed strikes, parries and takedowns, while also switching between your turtles to keep the combo going and the bad guys flying. It can be fast and extremely engaging to challenge yourself to do better and more stylish every time you try a stage. However, the turtles do feel like tanks, and they have the fluidity of cool magma. If you're a fan of the turtles, you can overlook this and get used to it, but if you're impartial to the heroes in a halfshell, you are right in thinking that you're holding a rather clunky game.

Furthermore, the music is dissapointment. Then again, every turtle game since Turtles in Time has had dissapointing music. What's also dissapointing is its design. Certain stages throw obstacles at you that are completely counter intuitive to what you'd expect from the game. The bosses in particular are just a gigantic headache, even if you've mastered the control scheme, they're still a complete mess.

However, the presentation is quite impressive. The main menu is an inviting rendition of the turtle lair, and each option takes you to a new place. On top of that, there are plenty of other modes to try when you've completed the short campaign. Especially the arcade mode, which harkens back to the original beat 'em up, is a treat if you're able to stomach the unfair final boss. Just get a friend on the couch, a slice of pizza, and just coop like the old day. Put on some 16-bit soundtrack goodness for the full package and you might you find this game growing on you in spite of its numerous flaws.

The online option is busted, so if you cannot couch coop, then you might want to consider getting a few friends before buying the game ;).

Update 2/1/2015: Realized I didn't make this review very objective. Edited it to be more rounded with better reasoning to my decisions and experience with the game. I want a reader to have a fair understanding of the game before they play/purchase. Hopefully this review can more effectively do that now.

Cons:

-The controls for this game are in spite of the player. The camera pans in different directions and, despite some maneuverability, the player really has absolutely no control over 75% of the time. Occasionally looking around is possible in open areas, but it'll easily be redirected in combat, or when you get into areas--like hallways or corners--where it forces you into one specific view point.

-Combat in the game acted more like a mobile app than an intuitive combat experience. Very much a button-mash experience using plain combos of click-click-click-other click.

-Inventory is difficult to shuffle through in combat when you have more than a few items. Two types of shuriken, two bombs, and the specialty weapons all filling the same slot, and only one key in one direction to alternate through, meant I was generally ignoring most of my inventory. Ideally, one could set each turtle with a different item, but if I wanted to toss a bomb in one direction and eat a pizza before going to a specialty weapon (as an example), I'd be bouncing around endlessly.

-In general exploration, I would have often preferred NOT having the other three turtles present throughout the game. I find they often get in the way.  I had many experiences with them blocking doorways or alleys that forced me to switch to a different character in order to move beyond.

As an example to the presence of the other turtles: There's a point in the game where you're running an obstacle course.  When your brothers fall behind, you'll get a puff from a smoke bomb that has the game replacing them next to you (this was my experience, at least).  When trying to make it through the course, I would continually get smoke bombed and blockaded by another turtle.  In this instance that one or two second stop meant failure, and became frustrating. I found this feature overall difficult and unwanted. I could have easily preferred an option to shut it off. Even when telling the others to stay here
date:
after a certain range, the game auto-moves them to meet the player.

-Lack of Sandbox option.

-No Jump (What kind of Ninja can't Jump?)

-Glitches in the Game. Certain areas are tied to timers that force a player to wait before advancing based on a predetermined expectation for defeating a set number of enemies. This occurred to me at least two or three times, and in one area I reset the game three times believing it to be a glitch. Turtles will get stuck in the geometry/surroundings a lot, player too.

Pros:
-The Art Direction of the game is fantastic. The turtles are not quite what I'd have hoped them to be from a game being produced through Nickelodeon given the design of the current-set on air. The realistic looks are a sort-of cross between the animated turtles, and the TMNT live-action from 2014. Real-looking, but without the excess junk, and physically similar to that animated ones in body proportions.

-The world is well thought out, a real chunk of New York City. Plenty to look at eye-candy wise, but don't hold your breath because it's no sandbox. Expect invisible barriers all over.

TMNT is a piece of my childhood that I love, and I've played the games as far back as NES/Gameboy.  This one was a real let down in terms of performance.  This could have been a fantastic sandbox, but the inability to even Jump let me know I probably wasn't going to enjoy the game.  From the lackluster combat, poor camera, continual timer delays witholding zone progression, and being stuck within the geometry often, I couldn't continue playing the game.

No amount of nostalgia could win this for me.  At best, I'd give it 4/10. Time to take it back into the shadows.

reviewText:
I am going to keep this review as short as possible.

First, let us get the negatives out of the way. I have encountered ugly textures, game breaking AI problems (final shredder fight), health packs (pizzas) that I literally could not pick up, and a combat system that almost does well at copying the Arkham series but falls short. OH! To top it off combat can be extremely punishing at times because you cannot block/counter in the middle of a combo but the enemies can still hit you.

The positives of the game are up next. Dialogue is between the turtles is pretty funny though can get repetitive. Combos when done without being interrupted by attacking enemies look cool. The ability to chain attacks with the other turtles and interact together while fighting is fun as well.

The only real selling point of this game is local coop and nostalgia, because the game length is extremely short. The total playtime to finish the main campaign (4 LEVELS) is approximately 30-40 minutes per level assuming you do not die, so about 2 hours long. True, there is the arcade mode, and player challenges that rank you on some kind of world leaderboard but the main campaign is short.

Overall I like the spirit of the game and am going to recommend it because the price tag of 15 dollars seems appropriate. However the game will probably still leave a bad taste in the mouths of those that expect a lot from the game. If you pick this game up, play it with a friend because playing this game alone will probably wish you were a Krang, or maybe misery loves company.

reviewText:
Sorry dudes. I've given this game multiple chances and it seems to only get worse and worse the more I play it.

A lot of it boils down to a lack of polish. Control feedback is sluggish. Granted, it does respond... in fact, it responds to every press, so if you mash buttons like a mad man, the turtle will keep going until it's responded to every button press. Now, if you're privy to pressing the A button (or acrobatics button) over and over again, your turtle's going to be cartwheeling, backflipping and jumping like a maniac for each press of the button. Oddly enough, when you have to actually dodge enemy attacks, it only works when it wants to, which is usually a second or two after you press the button, so you get your head kicked in anyway. Then there's counterattacking, where you usually have a fairly small window to act on or else, you'll get whacked. Now, when you got sluggish response times... let's just say you really have to get used to this, which is ridiculous.

Furthermore, the camera eats. Moving it around requires more fiddling than Operation since it's so bloody sensitive, Revengeance would blush! Now, for a game that requires you to time counterattacks and dodging just right, it doesn't seem to give you a good view of the action. While moving the camera around to get the right angle, it ends up zooming in too close into the action anyway. At least when you're wailing on enemies and you point the left stick or WASD keys towards a nearby enemy, you'll rush towards them and beat them up. This might not have been an issue if there was a lock on feature. This would certainly make boss fights more tolerable since you can actually focus on them, never mind enemy encounters so you can focus on them a bit better than just seeing your turtle smack them around. Maybe zoom the camera out a bit so there's less chance of another enemy sucker punching you and there you go, most of the camera issues solved.

It's also fairly glitchy - during the Mouser Cerberus fight, for instance, I suddenly teleported like 10 feet into the direction I held the left side. There was also one instance of waiting like two minutes before I could initiate a hacking mini game. Other reviews, both from release and even now, are pointing out more, though however much of it is due to this being a straight console port or not is up in the air. I'll admit that despite these three issues, I had fun at first. Yeah, there were some big issues that cropped up pretty quickly and on the whole, combat doesn't have as much oomph as the Arkham games or Sleeping Dogs, but I could at least chalk that up to being Red Fly Studio's first game - maybe they'll get it right next time??? Plus aside from some texture pop in, it looked good, the music wasn't half bad, the story was serviceable, and the dialogue was occasionally funny with that old TMNT charm. But yeah, there's only so much one can put up with before they lose their patience completely and drop the game in favor of a totally different game - preferably one that actually feels finished.

reviewText:
I beat Turtles: Out of the Shadows (TMNT:OotS) and I found it very disapointing. I wonder who found this to be a good game? It’s clear that the people who worked on this game were fans of the movies. The theme song is from the original movie, the team attacks are taken from the movies as well, and the team taunt is from the infamous Vanilla Ice scene. There are other references to the comics from the original pose on the rooftops to Don using a gravity gun a la the original micro series issue. There’s some more lore in there, but from all of that it’s clear this wasn’t just some fan candy, but clearly there were some fans of the franchise on the team building the game.

I bring all this up because it’s so odd to see a game where there’s a clear love for the material in the details then the game to just fall flat. I want to talk about the game from the end and kind of work back. If you’re worried about spoilers, let me dispel any worry for you. You need to beat up shredder, and you do, twice.

In the final fight Shredder’s big upgrade is supposed to be teleporting. This might of seemed like a difficult thing to deal with sure. But because the game had been glitching the entire time so even the lowliest gang member had this ability from the get go. Plus you can too when during certain combos you will shift on screen from one enemy to the next. Oh and let’s not forget one of the other boss battles, Kari who teleports as well. All of these bosses have something else in common as well, there might be some set up, but in the end you need all 4 turtles punching and kicking waiting to land a hit, no pattern no rhyme or reason just keep punching till it’s over. Maybe there was supposed to be something more here, but nothing in the game would lead you to that.

The combat is clearly inspired by the Batman Arkham games. So look for the indicator to block, go for combos for points, the more you combo and pull special moves the more upgrades you can get. There’s no real difference between the characters until you upgrade them, and even then it’s only slight.

To try to find some more positive I know some people are put off by the character redesigns but in motion of the game it seems to work and each turtle has their own look and the enemies all are owning their own feel, in looks anyways.

The sound is a bit of a mixed bag. The music is pretty forgettable, but isn’t holding anything back. The turtles random lines can be fun the first time you hear them, but then they can get caught in a loop where they’re literally be repeated 3 times in a row. Then a random clip can actually cut over a plot point of dialogue, so it’s very possible I missed a good portion of the story.

So TLDR: Punch Kick, doesn’t matter it’s all in your mind, just mash to victory.

I hope I can dissuade anyone else from picking this up. It’s sad to see it fall flat, but it’s clear it was rushed and under budget.

reviewText:
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows is a third-person brawler with an RPG-lite leveling system and plenty of Ninja Turtle nostalgia.
There are four modes available Campaign, Arcade Mode, Challenge Mode and Dojo Training. The game can also be played in multiplayer, local and online.
The 4-player co-op online multiplayer is currently not working.
You take on the role of Donatello, Michelangelo, Raphael and Leonardo as they serve up justice to evildoers and their armies of minions. All sorts of TMNT favorites show up Baxter, the Foot, Shredder, April O'Neil, etc.
The story missions serve up a mix of third-person brawling with light stealth, platforming and even a hacking minigame thrown in.
Enemies will swarm you, even with four turtles, you are still going to be outnumbered in most battles. This is potentially exciting because the extra bodies let you attain high combo numbers and pull off more-powerful moves.
Unfortunately, the camera often jerks around too wildly for you to see what is happening. Special moves yank the camera too close to the action. Depending on what sort of acrobatics you are performing, the camera might spin or zoom on its own, disorienting you in the middle of a longer attack.
You might not get into combat at all because enemies are often stuck in the walls. If you do not cross the invisible line that spawns enemies in the first place, you are left to roam an empty environment wondering what went wrong until all you can do is to restart from the last checkpoint.
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows could have been a fun but because of all the bugs and glitches you will forget all about that potential.
My advice if you are a hardcore TMNT fan buy it after a few updates or wait until the price is reduced.

reviewText:
Ok, a warning beforehand: I am biased toward anything Turtles. It doesn't matter if it's a turd with a red bandana, I am bound to like it. With that out of the way, let's get this review trucking.

Out of the Shadows is a freeflow combat beat 'em up loosly adapted from the 2012 Nickelodeon reboot of the series. If you haven't seen that yet, give it a shot. It captures much of the old magic in a more modern and sensible jacket than the 80s cartoon. The game however, wears a different coat. The Turtles all have a more realistic look; they look like genuine mutants. This is probably the most striking feature of the game, because it departs from the appearances we's come be familliar with.

The gameplay itself though is a bit of a mix between Batman Arkham Asylum and Turtles in Time. You control one Turtle at a time, but you can switch at the touch of a button. You fight your way through hordes of mooks by using wel timed strikes, parries and takedowns, while also switching between your turtles to keep the combo going and the bad guys flying. It can be fast and extremely engaging to challenge yourself to do better and more stylish every time you try a stage. However, the turtles do feel like tanks, and they have the fluidity of cool magma. If you're a fan of the turtles, you can overlook this and get used to it, but if you're impartial to the heroes in a halfshell, you are right in thinking that you're holding a rather clunky game.

Furthermore, the music is dissapointment. Then again, every turtle game since Turtles in Time has had dissapointing music. What's also dissapointing is its design. Certain stages throw obstacles at you that are completely counter intuitive to what you'd expect from the game. The bosses in particular are just a gigantic headache, even if you've mastered the control scheme, they're still a complete mess.

However, the presentation is quite impressive. The main menu is an inviting rendition of the turtle lair, and each option takes you to a new place. On top of that, there are plenty of other modes to try when you've completed the short campaign. Especially the arcade mode, which harkens back to the original beat 'em up, is a treat if you're able to stomach the unfair final boss. Just get a friend on the couch, a slice of pizza, and just coop like the old day. Put on some 16-bit soundtrack goodness for the full package and you might you find this game growing on you in spite of its numerous flaws.

The online option is busted, so if you cannot couch coop, then you might want to consider getting a few friends before buying the game ;).

reviewText:
There's a lot of hate on the sake of multiplayer, but  This game is EXCELLENT, and Here, I'll prove it.

Okay, so the controls can be a bit delayed in response time, but the game is a great one, a challenge like most would claim they live for.

A very short game of only four chapters, yet it feels like forever due to some of the difficult battles. BUt the satisfaction is worth it. The game is not impossible. Co=operation is key.

PLay as any of the iconic turtles on the fly. Not only that, perform incredible team moves, attacks, and knockouts in your quest to beat Shredder! Going across a variety of beatuifully rendered settings, you'll find a new love for the turtles you enjoyed as a kid. RPG elements make the game treat as you level up the turtles to suit your playstyle with a variety of team manuevers, stat boosts, even combos and counters, these can make the game even more spectacular!

Also, unlock unique weapons for the turtles to use. Leo's Bladestaff, DOnnie Grav Gauntlet, Raph's Iron fist, and a Kusarigama for Mikey. (Should he be playing with something that sharp?)

these open up unique special attacks, but sadly do not get integrated into combos. The look bad ♥♥♥ though, so...that's something.

There're also other modes. Take it streets-of-rage style in arcade mode, a nice little side-scrolling beat-em-up minigame. Or, go head to head with the baddies from the areas in the story, from the alleyways and rooftops to the sewers and shredhead's throne room.

Not feeling confident in your skills? Practice in the dojo! Practice makes perfect ninjas, after all.

An overall rating?...7/10.

Could have been longer, could have made more minigames, and I suppose the boss fights could be a bit easier, but, the fun is in the challenge, right? Ha.

reviewText:
So, I only recently got into TMNT after watching some of the recent 2012 series and got hooked pretty fast. I remembered hearing about this game on launch and that it was plagued with bugs and to avoid. After watching the series I decided to bite the bullet and try out a TMNT game. I'm glad I did.

The main focus of the game is it's combat system, which plays like the Arkham Series and Street Fighter had a baby. While at the start you have some pretty basic moves, you earn XP and level up your turtles until you get some pretty awesome moves and abilities. It has the same counter-move system as Arkham does but also has button combos and special abilities that use the stick in circles to activate. You build up your combo meter until you can either do a takedown or throw an enemy. Where this gets really interesting is the other turtles. All 4 of you fight in combat at the same time, and you can do combined takedowns and throws on more powerful enemies and also do team up attacks. You can even call in a team mate to keep up an air juggle another character started, or assist in a dodge or combo. All 4 characters are playable, can be swapped out at any time (even during combat). And there is so much more. For a beat-em up game, the combat system has a crazy amount of depth to it. Fortunately every move has a tutorial in the dojo, as well as freestyles for you to practice your moves.

The game as a whole is pretty short. It is based upon the 2012 CGI series. The main campaign is around 4 hours long and while there are some minor platforming sections and a hacking minigame, the focus is on the combat system. Outside of the short campaign, you have a challenge mode (which is really just the combat challenge maps from Arkham) and an old style beat-em-up version of the story which has 4 player local co-op. Unfortunately that's it in terms of content, so it's pretty short.

The graphics are honestly pretty damn good for £12 game. There is some pretty muddy texture work here and there but the turtles themselves and the enemies look great. They went with a more 'realistic' look compared to the show it's based on. The main selling point of the graphics is the fantastic animation of the turtles. All 4 have their own style and animations and when in the thick of combat it all looks pretty awesome. Performance was not an issue at all for me at 1920x1080, but I do play on a pretty powerful laptop. On that note, the graphics settings are very minimal, pretty much just resolution and that's about it.

Admittedly, I encountered a fair few bugs and glitches during the game, but none of them gamebreaking. A few points of floating in place or teleporting during combat, and even with the camera mod it did wig out once or twice, but that was it. I guess a lot of the jankiness from launch appears to be fixed. Or I was just really lucky. One problem I did have was the game has no objective marker, and in a few of the levels I did get lost and confused as to what I was meant to do next.

I cannot comment on the multiplayer as I have not tried online or split-screen. I will update soon when I drag a friend over to try it out.

Overall, it's a very solid game primarily for it's amazing combat system, which in my opinion blows Arkham's out of the water. When in a big fight with all 4 turtles it is quite the sight to behold. If you are a turtles fan I would highly recommend, and if you're not watch some of the series and see if you like what you see, get this game.

reviewText: I've heard the online multiplayer doesn't work, but some say it has been fixed recently, and besides that there are user guides on how to modify the game to play multiplayer if these claims are false. You'll probably see lots of people complaining that the multiplayer doesn't work, and the game is impossible without it. This is a blatant lie. I beat the Cerberus boss on my 3rd attempt, and the final boss on my 20th. Roughly. I took a month long break from the game, came back, beat it first try. I love this game, it is not only the best TMNT game I have ever played, but also one of the best games I've ever played. It's probably up there with Arkham Asylum, since that game was the worst of the franchise. I recommend this to anyone who enjoyed that game, and any TMNT fan. A quick side note, I used a user guide to modify the games files and change the keybindings to something I was more comfortable with. Most people will probably get on fine with a controller, but personally, I hate those things. The Survival mode is very fun, even if it is frustrating at times. Having to play the same 4 levels over and over again to level up and unlock all the moves, also frustrating. However the core gameplay, while repetitive, is tons of fun and mostly makes up for that. I love playing the challenges trying to beat my score, and as a person who makes skin mods, I can add further playability to a game I already completely adore. In my screenshots I have some pictures of a Cyber Turtles mod. TL; DR In conclusion, the game has a few walls you may need to get past, especially if you're playing on your own, but it is completely worth it, as the game is tons of fun. Taking advantage of special moves is important to succeed.

reviewText:
This game is a third person action RPG essentially, with a list of negative flaws.
I have spent over 36 hours playing this game, and after playing everything including ONLINE CO OP (yes it works), I just can't reccommend this game to anyone for the full price.
TMNT has you controlling all 4 turtles at once through a Story Mode that consists of only 4 stages, as well as some other gamestyles such as Challenge Mode, Arcade Mode, and Survival Mode. The game has Leaderboards for some of the gamestyles.
I do consider this game an action RPG as it has an experience and ability point system that allows you to increase the stats of the turtles, allowing them to have a larger variety of moves they can do in battle.
You control one turtle while the other turtles are A.I. controlled, but you can switch to them at almost anytime.

The highlights of this game for me was the somewhat fluid battle system which I enjoyed learning and the turtles relationship both in and out of battle. The turtles combine their attacks and specials together during battle, and talk about all kinds of things during the stages.The controls and battle system take some getting used too of course, and i actually have little complaints about that part of the game. They did well with the controls.
The ability to switch to any character during the game was a cool idea, and it allows you to use some of the turtles out of battle skills such as Don's increased control device hacking ability.

The game does have a great look and unique feel to it, but here we run out of good things to say...

The game has horrible video settings to choose from. On my computer, it only offered me three choices on display resolution and little else useful. There were no texture settings or shadows or anything like that unless you go into the .ini file. The game runs well for me though on a Core 2 Duo 1.87 Ghz with a GeForce GT 430 @ 1280x720.
Expect a lot of conversation between the Turtles at the worst possible times generally. You can turn voices off though in settings if you want.
Online co op is a big highlight here, however it does not work as well as you would hope. Steam invites do not work, but hosting a quick match seems to help. You can only play story mode though. The game seems to have in game voice chat which worked for me.
The big issue I have with this game is the price, the bugs, and the amount of gameplay you get here. With only four Story Mode stages I found that to be pathetic, especially compared to the other Turtles games from the past. The maps are a decent lengh, but you'll breeze through them.
There are some other game modes I mentioned, but they are played in the same stages as Story Mode with the same enemies. It's just doing the same thing in a slightly different way.
Finally, there are many bugs I've seen in this game, such as interacting with team attacks when your across the map and kicking at nothing in the air, or using special moves and finding your weapon following you around like a floating object.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=488745809

How about spawning on the opposite side of a locked room because you were too far away from the other turtles and having to switch to get to the other side? (Not a big deal but shouldn't happen).
The camera I found to be REALLY bad. You will constantly need to adjust it as it likes to move around and zoom in and out in the heat of battle causing you view to be obstructed by floating crossbeams above you.
The ending was terrible too. Just kill him already, it's been like 20+ years guy.

Don't buy this game for full price like I did. It's not worth it.

I had some fun but I would rather play something else.

This game comes across to me as a mix of old-school fighters, arcade beat-em-ups, and modern batman-esque fighting mechanics and upgrade system.

I haven't personally tried the co-op, though I imagine it will still be fun as I've managed to overcome many of the game's shortcomings as a polished game.

I wish that the game had been completed a little better, but overall it is WAY more than I ever expected to see in a TMNT game and I hope that there are more like it in the future.

reviewText:
This game is weird and kinda crappy at first.
However, once you fix it, it's really fun and addictive!
For me, Motion Blur was the main problem.
So, I went into:
steam//steamapps//common//TMNT-Oots//Engine//Config
Then I turned off Motion blur, as well as Dynamic lights.
Works like a charm, and it's very fun!

reviewText:
Good stuff: This game has a simple, yet great looking, combat system, parkour that makes you feel badass, and a wonderful portrayal of the turtles personalities. All the little references make it a blast for fans how know a lot of turtle lore.

Bad stuff: The Graphics are not great and the voice acting is mediocre at best. April looks like a half melted Mcdonalds toy, you can tell they didn't spend much time on her.


Overall, if you are a fan of the turtles this game will be fun for you, if you aren't it probably won't be.

reviewText: You will encounter a few bugs every so often. Some bugs halt your progress as they disable your movement, forcing you to switch out characters or just reset the level. The one special attack requires you to hold the right trigger and rotate the right stick clockwise, but can't seem to get that to work. Voice, dialog, sound, its all good. The Unreal Engine looks good and makes the textures and normals stand out. But gosh darn is this game purple as ****.
